questions.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with infertility. During the procedure, the surgeon notices powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera is seen in pelvic endometriosis. 

Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/gunshot appearance seen on the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or can be small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish-brown fluid which has prostaglandins responsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: Chocolate cyst (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

Powder burn appearance:

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with oliguria, abdominal distension, and pedal edema. His medical records show long-standing cirrhosis with multiple hospitalisations for ascites and hepatic encephalopathy. His lab reports are given below. What is the best treatment for his condition?

AST- 148 U/L

ALT- 64 U/L

Total bilirubin- 8.9 mg/dL

Sr. Creatinine- 7.6 mg/dL

Blood urea nitrogen- 84 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatorenal syndrome. The best treatment modality for it is liver transplantation.

Hepatorenal syndrome is characterised by a rise in:

  • AST
  • ALT
  • Total bilirubin
  • Serum creatinine
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN).

Management of hepatorenal syndrome include:

  • Norepinephrine
  • Octreotide
  • Terlipressin
  • Midodrine
  • Intravenous albumin 
  • Liver transplantation- definitive treatment

questions.text: The corneal epithelium is composed of_______.
questions.solution:
The corneal epithelium is made up of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium.

Layers of the cornea

  • Epithelium (Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium)
    • A single layer of columnar basal cells attached by hemidesmosomes to an underlying basement
      membrane
    • Limbal stem cells are located at the corneoscleral limbus, possibly in the palisades of Vogt. Deficiency may result in chronic epithelial defects and "conjunctivalization" (epithelial instability, vascularization, and the appearance of goblet cells)
    • Complete turnover of corneal epithelial cells occurs in about 7–10 days.
  • Bowman’s membrane
    • Acellular superficial layer of the stroma formed from collagen fibers.
    • Does not regenerate
  • Stroma (Thickest layer)
    • Makes up 90% of corneal thickness
    • Contains chondroitin sulphate (dermatan sulphate) and keratan sulphate.
    • The stroma can scar, but cannot regenerate the subsequent damage.
  • Dua’s layer (Newly discovered, toughest layer)
  • Descemet’s membrane
    • Ends peripherally as Schwalbe’s ring
    • Has regenerative potential
  • Endothelium (Most metabolically active layer)
    • Does not regenerate
    • Endothelial cells maintain corneal deturgescence

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came with a headache and decreased urine output. On examination her BP was 150/90mmhg and abdominal bruits were heard.  Renal angiography was done. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the condition shown in the image given below:

choices.text: Most common site of involvement is renal artery
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
The image shows "strings of beads appearance" on CT angiography which is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common limb artery affected is iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia:

  • Segmentally affected, non-atheromatous and dysplastic type of angiopathy
  • Predominantly affects females
  • The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia
  • The most common site of involvement is renal > carotid > limb arteries
  • The most common limb artery affected is the iliac arteries.
  • CT  angiography shows a ‘string of beads’ appearance.
  • Can also present as renal aneurysms.

questions.text: The Nuclear scan used for the detection of Meckel’s diverticulum:
questions.solution:
• Tc 99m Pertechnetate is used for detection of Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate:
    • Thyroid imaging
    • Meckel scan
    • Testicle imaging
    • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from thyroid gland
    • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above image points show lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm which are characteristics of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

 Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.

Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

ALL is more common in childhood. The child had symptoms related to depression of marrow function including pallor, weight loss due to anemia and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration.

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population tends to be homogeneous Blast population tends to be heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size is variable, mainly small  Size is variable, mainly large 
Nucleus is central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Nucleus tends to be eccentric, round, oval or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin is fine, with dispersed condensation 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Chromatin is fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli absent in small lymphoblasts 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Nucleoli almost always present, often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm is scanty, basophilic 
Sometimes with a single long projection (‘hand-mirror cell’) 		 Cytoplasm is variable; 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules are rarely present; Negative for peroxidase, esterases and toluidine blue  Granules present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and esoinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods are absent  Auer rods can be present; 
Typically present in the hypergranular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles can be present Vacuoles can be present; 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component

questions.text: “Social smile” is typically seen at ____ months and “stranger anxiety,” at ____ months.
questions.solution:
Social smile is typically seen at 2 months and stranger anxiety at 6 months.

Social smile: At 1 month of age, a child smiles involuntarily. At 2 months of age social smile develops; that is, the child smiles voluntarily and reciprocally, in response to someone else’s smile.

Stranger anxiety: Before 6 months, the child is sociable and friendly even with strangers. At 6 months, there is an onset of stranger anxiety; infants look back and forth between an approaching stranger and parent and may cling or cry anxiously.

Related Pearl: Social and adaptive milestones

 
Age
Milestone
2 months
Social smile
3 months
Recognizes mother
6 months
Stranger anxiety
9 months
Waves bye-bye
12 months
Comes when called
Plays simple ball game
15 months
Jargon
18 months
Copies parents in the task
2 years
Asks for food, drink, toilet
3 years
Shares toys
Knows full name and gender
4 years
Plays cooperatively in a group and goes to the toilet alone
5 years
Helps in household tasks and can dress and undress on its own

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • The optimal time for performing CECT is more than 72 h after the onset of symptoms (In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis).

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gall stone induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the investigation of choice. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

 Balthazar Score

Balthazar Grade

Appearance on CT

CT Grade Points

Grade A

Normal CT

  0 Points
 

Grade B

 Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas  1 Point
 

Grade C

 Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation   2 Points

Grade D

 		 Fluid collection in a single location  3 Points
 

Grade E

 Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas  4 Points
Necrosis Score  

Necrosis Percentage

  

Points

No necrosis

    

0 Points

 
 

0 to 30% necrosis

    

2 Points

 
 

30 to 50% necrosis

  

4 Points

 

 
 

Over 50% necrosis

    6 Points

 

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points.

questions.text: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

choices.text: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.solution:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.

Indications of episiotomy:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:

  • Avoid delivery by early extension
  • Deliver head in between contractions
  • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.text: Late signs of death are all except:
questions.solution:
Putrefaction, adipocere formation, mummification are late signs of death whereas suggilation/postmortem hypostasis is an early sign of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: An employee diagnosed with TB gets extended sickness benefit for:
questions.solution:
Extended sickness benefit is for 2 years.

Few important points to be known about the ESI act:

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill.
  • Employee contributes 0.75% of wages.
  • State and Central government share medical expenditure in the ratio 1:7.
  • Medical benefit: Full medical care
  • Sickness benefit: 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days.
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseaes, diabetes, Parkinsons, Myasthenia Gravis, Glaucoma, Coronary artery disease etc.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.
  • Maternity benefit: Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy.
  • Funeral expenses: Cash not exceeding Rs.15,000.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of COVID-19?

choices.text: Reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction test

questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of Covid-19 is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.

RT-PCR: This method involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA.

Rapid antigen test (RAT): Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

Antibody testing: Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

questions.text: True statement about intermittent claudication:

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles because of the involvement of the superficial femoral artery in chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day.

Rest pain signifies critical limb ischemia, occurring due to the worsening of perfusion to the muscle.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presented with complaints of bluish-black discolouration of sclera and pinna for last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine turns black on standing as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria and results due to excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

It is an autosomal recessive condition due to deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase).

The homogentisic acid is then oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-coloured alkapton bodies, which deposits in soft tissues like cartilage and is called as ochronosis.

Image A - Normal urine
Image B - Alkaptonuria

Related Pearl: Metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Disorder

Enzyme defect

Phenylketonuria

Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Tyrosinosis (Tyrosinemia type I)

Maleyl Acetate isomerase or Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Maple syrup urine disease 

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD)

Alkaptonuria

Homogentisate oxidase

Albinism

Tyrosinase

Homocystinuria type I

Cystathionine synthase

Homocystinuria type II

Defect in methylcobalamin formation

Cystathioninuria

Cystathionase

Tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome

Tyrosine transaminase or Tyrosine aminotransferase

Primary hyperoxaluria

Alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase

Hypervalinemia

Valine transaminase

Isovaleric acidemia

Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase

Histidinemia

Histidase

Hyperprolinemia type I

Proline oxidase

questions.text:
A 25-year-old infertile male underwent semen analysis. 
Results show: sperm concentration - 16 million/ml: pH- 7.5: volume - 2 mL: no agglutination is seen. 
Morphology shows 60% normal and 60% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
This male with sperm concentration 16 million/mL is considered to be normospermia.

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL.

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Latest WHO standard for semen analysis - 2021:

Semen analysis Normal reference value
Semen volume  >1.5 mL
Sperm concentration 15 million/mL
pH >7.2
Total sperm number  >39 million/ejaculate
Total motility  >40%
Progressive motility  >32%
Vitality  >58% live sperm
Normal forms   >4%
Agglutination Particles <2

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

  • Volume: 1.5 mL
  • PH: 7.2–7.8
  • Viscosity : <3 (scale 0–4)
  • Sperm concentration ≥15 million/mL 
  • Total sperm count: ≥39 million/per ejaculate 
  • Motility: 40% or more with 32% progressive motility
  • Forward progression: >2 (Scale of 0-4)
  • Normal forms: 4% (strict criteria) 
  • Vitality: 58% or more 
  • White blood cells: < 1 million/mL
  • Round cells: 5 million/mL
  • Sperm agglutination: <2 (Scale 0-3)

questions.text: Following a motor vehicle collision, a 30-year-old male sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen. What is the organ most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The spleen is the most common organ involved in blunt trauma injury of the abdomen.

In blunt trauma, organs that cannot yield to impact by elastic deformation are most likely to be injured, namely, the solid organs (liver, spleen, and kidneys).

For penetrating trauma, organs with the largest surface area when viewed from the front are most prone to injury (small bowel, liver, and colon). Additionally, since bullets and knives usually follow straight lines, adjacent structures are commonly injured (e.g., the pancreas and duodenum).

Deceleration injures the pedicled organs by shearing the organs from their points of attachment to the retroperitoneum (intestines and kidney).

The most commonly injured bowel in cases of blunt trauma of the abdomen is jejunum.

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray image are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accident). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

The radiographic image shows oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum known as involucrum. 

The characteristic radiographic features of other conditions given are:

Osteogenic sarcoma - Sun-burst appearance, Codman's triangle

Ewing's sarcoma - Onion skin appearance

Multiple myeloma - Punched out lesions

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): The Arnold's nerve innervates the skin over a small part of the ear and external auditory canal. In patients with chronic cough, scratching or mechanical stimulation of ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough.

Causes of referred otalgia Nerve responsible Site
Temporomandibular joint and dental conditions, parotid infections/tumor, and anterior 2/3rd of tongue Auriculotemporal nerve Tragal area, crus of the helix, and anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal. 
Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, carcinoma base of the tongue or tonsils (oropharynx) The glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's) Medial surface of the tympanic membrane, and middle ear
Carcinoma of the larynx (cough), hypopharynx, epiglottis, vallecula, esophagus, and thyroid Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's/Alderman's nerve) Concha, posterior wall, and floor of the external auditory canal
Cervical spondylitis Great auricular nerve (C2,3) Lateral and medial surfaces of the pinna
Acoustic neuroma Facial nerve (nervus intermedius/nerve of Wrisberg)

Concha, retro auricular groove, and posterosuperior part of the external auditory meatus. Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall known as Hitzelberger's sign, is seen in acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.

In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. 

Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:

  • Antibiotic use
  • Advanced age
  • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers
  • Immunosuppression

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the casualty department with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. His attender reported that he had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and had recently started treatment. What is the drug of choice to treat the patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced parkinsonism, for which the drug of choice is benzhexol, also known as trihexiphenidyl. 

Benzhexol is an antimuscarinic agent. Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol acts by restoring the balance of the cholinergics in the striatal interneurons.

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Drug class

Examples 
Typical antipsychotics

Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics Metoclopramide, levosulpiride
Calcium channel blockers Flunarizine, cinnarizine

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with patchy hair loss, characterized by short, broken strands appearing together with long, normal hairs in the affected areas. No abnormalities of the skin or scalp are present. Biopsy shows perifollicular hemorrhage. The probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
The given history and findings suggest a diagnosis of Trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania:

  • A chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by repetitive hair pulling, leading to variable hair loss.
  • There is increased tension prior to the hair pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair pulling.
  • More common in females.
  • Trichophagy
    • Eating hair may follow the hair plucking.
    • Complications of trichophagy include trichobezoars, malnutrition, and intestinal obstruction
  • Biopsy: Perifollicular hemorrhages present.

Other options:

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. 

The image below shows alopecia areata:

Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows tinea capitis:

Anagen effluvium is Alopecia after chemotherapy. Hair loss following chemotherapy usually occurs within 1–3 weeks after initiation of the therapy. In this type of hair loss, the anagen phase is abruptly terminated. This leads to the loss of dystrophic or broken hair and the condition is called anagen effluvium. The hair loss is acute and diffuse. However, there is full recovery within a few months of stopping the causative drug. 

The image below shows Anagen effluvium :

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.text: A worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray.

The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. 

Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques are calcified resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Related Pearl: Occupational Lung Diseases

Occupational lung diseases

Occupation / Cause

Asbestosis

Shipping, textile, cement and roofing sheet manufacturing industries

Silicosis

Mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass manufacturing, quarrying industries

Bagassosis

Sugarcane fibers

Byssinosis (brown lung disease/ Monday fever) 

Cotton, flax, hemp, and jute fiber

Farmer’s lung

Thermophilic actinomycetes 

Bird Fancier’s lung

 Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by bird droppings   
Chalicosis (flint disease)  In stonecutters, due to inhalation of fine particles of stone

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of tumor is:
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of layers of epidermis from deep to superficial?

choices.text: Stratum basale, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum corneum
Stratum basale, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum corneum
Stratum corneum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum basale
Stratum corneum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum basale

questions.solution:
The correct order of the given layers from deep to superficial is stratum basale, stratum spinosum, stratum granulosum, stratum corneum.

 

LAYERS OF SKIN (superficial to deep):

Thin skin

Thick skin

(glabrous skin)

palms, soles, flexor surfaces of digits
  • stratum corneum
  • stratum granulosum
  • stratum spinosum
  • stratum basale
  • stratum corneum
  • stratum lucidum
  • stratum granulosum
  • stratum spinosum
  • stratum basale

Mnemonic for skin layers (superficial to deep): Come Let's Get Some Beer (Corneum, Lucidum, Granulosum, Spinosum, and Basale).

questions.text: Vasopressin has maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: While collecting data on nail changes in psoriasis patients, you note the following findings. Which of the following is the most specific finding for this condition?
questions.solution:
Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch (image C), a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil. The reddish-brown color is due to dilated, tortuous, superficial capillaries in the papillary dermis and parakeratosis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the national vector-borne disease control program. Identify the disease caused by this vector.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese Encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs.

questions.text: A screening test gave positive results in 60% of the diseased individuals and 20% of the healthy individuals. Calculate the specificity for this test.
questions.solution:
The specificity of a test from the given information can be calculated as 0.8.

60% of individuals having the disease came out to be positive. So for 100 diseased individuals, 60 are True positives and 40 are False negatives.

20% of the individuals not having the disease came out to be positive. so for 100 healthy individuals, 20 are False positives and 80 are true negatives.

The specificity of a test is given by those who are healthy(do not have the disease) and test negative (true negatives) out of the total healthy population. So the specificity = TN divided by TN+FP, i.e 80/100= 0.8

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population. Here Sensitivity= TP/TP+FN = 60/100=0.6

The test's positive predictive value is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population. Here PPV= TP/TP+FP = 60/80=0.75

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population. NPV here= TN/TN+FN = 80/120=0.67

questions.text: Infection with hepatitis E virus has the highest fatality rate in which of the following populations?
questions.solution:
Fatality due to Hepatitis E is highest in pregnant women.

In the general population, hepatitis E can be complicated by fatal fulminant hepatitis in 1–2% of cases. But in pregnant women, it is raised to 20%.
